question: A simple pendulum has a period of 2 seconds. If the length of the pendulum is doubled, what will be the new period?
solution: The period of a simple pendulum is given by the formula T = 2π√(L/g), where L is the length of the pendulum and g is the acceleration due to gravity. If the length is doubled, the new period will be T_new = 2π√(2L/g). This can be simplified to T_new = √2 * 2π√(L/g) = √2 * T. Given the initial period T = 2 seconds, the new period will be T_new = √2 * 2 seconds = 2√2 seconds.
